data.text: How to Pack Panniers for a Flight

About to travel to Europe from Australia and wondering how people fly with their panniers? For example do you put them in a bag or wrap them in plastic. This is all of our luggage as we are picking up bikes over there. Thanks all lots of good ideas to work on. Cheers Adrian
Those cheap red and white and blue striped bags are quite handy. Keep one of your panniers as hand luggage
data.author: Paula Lilburne

data.text: More or less what says I use a huge plastic bag used by supermarkets here for collecting pet bottles returned by customers. Keep one back pannier out in which you put all your electronics and stuff you want to keep at hand and to keep the checked in piece below 23kg. I use tape to close it and add two tie-down straps to keep it together and make it easy to carry. Take the tape in your handluggage. You can use the plastic back under your tent when traveling.
data.author: Martin Koole

data.text: The tent floor thing is genius, thanks
data.author: Matthias Tango

data.text: Cardboard box.
data.author: Vlady Stroy

data.text: Laundry bags. Tape shut.
data.author: Sol Findley

data.text: The airline might charge you over pannier. I pack everything in a suitcase that doesn't fit in the bike case. I leave the bags at the place I'm flying in and out of or I ship it to the final destination. In your case you could buy something cheap in the airline restricted size and toss it when you're done. Just make sure you follow the guidelines of the airline you're flying. $$$$$$
data.author: Peter Sheridan

data.text: If they want to charge you per pannier, and they don't fit in suitcase (or you're not carrying one), I suggest IKEA Frakta trolley bag. Very sturdy, keeps your stuff together and has handles so it's kind to the handlers.
data.author: Stipe Stajp Predanic

data.text: By a big cheap duffel bag. 50 lbs per bag. Usually
data.author: Wayne Macdougall

data.text: Yup, cardboard box. Just make sure it’s not over weight. And take a Lanier or two as your carry on luggage
data.author: Sharon Neubauer Moore

data.text: I wish people posted questions like this more in the group. How do you travel, how do you pack, how do you eat, etc. People make it look easy but there are tips and tricks the rest of us should know that isn’t common sense.
data.author: Tom O. Ro

data.text: We use a bag cover, it fits 2panniers in and other random bits (handlebar bags, tents etc) then take the other 2 panniers as hand luggage. Folds up small to carry with you
data.author: Laura Lilypad

data.text: use this wey and com to cuba!🚴🚴🚵😊
data.author: Enrique Gil Jaular

data.text: Cling film 2 together
data.author: Tina Brocklebank

data.text: as mentioned above, we always use the big red/ white/ blue ‘homesless guy’ bags. the zips are not up to the job so we always tie the handles in a knot. Never had an issue or lost a pannier yet.
data.author: Craig Pullen

data.text: yep.... do the same! Sometimes difficult to find a very big "homeless" bag.
data.author: Mick Falk

data.text: $2 shops!
data.author: Kim Mcfadden

data.text: here in Germany there's TEDi, EuroShop, etc... just finding a "big" bag can be difficult at times.
data.author: Mick Falk

data.text: Ikea have cheap big plastic zip bags. We use one to put our panniers in then tape them up for added strength
data.author: Elizabeth Bush

data.text: I do the same
data.author: Renata Vallero Winzer

data.text: i use Ikea bag
data.author: Dragan Ognjanović

data.text: Big bags used for gardening (used to collect garden waste and to bring is to a container park)
data.author: Patrick Simoens

data.text: Last time I joined two together with a luggage strap through the handles, so the could still be picked up easily - seemed to work fine.
data.author: Lynne Granger

data.text: I put everything in a soft duffle bag that I can fold and store in a pannier at arrival.
data.author: Elie BD

data.text: We use the 'chinese' shopping bags. And then tape or do the clung film thing in the airport so they don't move around. Also we each have one of those bags with us atm in Europe. Sometimes if you get on a train or bus they will make you take the bags off. We just throw them in the bag and bob's your uncle.
data.author: Sharyn Nilsen
Sharyn Nilsen

data.text: yip that’s what I do … I keep the bags for the return trip
data.author: Renata Vallero Winzer

data.text: that's probs what we will do!😊
data.author: Virginia Yurisich

data.text: some airlines specify boxes.eg. Qatar from HCMC. Check before you go to the airport.
data.author: Sharyn Nilsen

data.text: thans for that, will do.
data.author: Virginia Yurisich

data.text: Bob is my uncle!
data.author: Matt R. Denney

data.text: mine too!
data.author: Sharyn Nilsen

data.text: is that a common phrase?
data.author: Matt R. Denney

data.text: was in Australia in my era. :)
data.author: Sharyn Nilsen

data.text: Awwwhhh… thanks…
data.author: Matt R. Denney

data.text: On many occasions yes wrap them up. But boy! The plastic is worrying. They’re usually fine. And turn up the other side 🙏 hsve a super cool trip 🐕
data.author: Paul Richardson

data.text: Haven’t read all the other comments so may be repeating. I tape all mine together into one big block at the airport using duck tape. Easier and cheaper checking in.
data.author: Declan Colley

data.text: We have 2 large Chinese shopping bags. Everything fits in them. They're heavy though, but easy to carry with you for trains and buses.
data.author: Tim Nilsen

data.text: Exactly the way I do it!
data.author: Supp Suppinger

data.text: great minds!
data.author: Tim Nilsen

data.text: Me too! AKA Ghana Bags!
data.author: John Bell

data.text: wrap in plastic 2 together if piece limited - customs might open it but they will tape or wrap it again
data.author: Josh Taylor

data.text: I have usually put mine, fully packed, in cardboard boxes (all 5 bags into one box) and tape them up well. I can then easily discard them when I reach my destination.
data.author: Þórður Ólafur Þórðarson

data.text: Travelled a lot on planes, I use big size carbage plastic bags, you buy ecwrywhere, use 3 bags or so for 2-3 panniers, use a roll of tape all round to hold it all together, use 1-2 front panniers as carry on bags (they fit the size) on the plane, easy, cheap abd ready to go (and you do not have to carry that stuff on the bike, just buy the sane on your way home)
data.author: Svend Jepsen

data.text: put some stuff in beside bike in cardboard box and i carried large cheap thin lightweight holdall (£14)with the rest of panniers in that so i only had one large bag at check in and a bike box.. then fold up hold all and stuff inside a pannier. (could throw it away also if its to bulky). other option that i have done is to strap all panniers together and cover with shink wrap but its mor awkward to carry them.
data.author: Scott Cunningham

data.text: no bikes, picking Them up in Europe
data.author: Adrian Yurisich

data.text: no worries ,,, i like Laura option below
data.author: Scott Cunningham

data.text: this was my way in April this year
data.author: Scott Cunningham

data.text: I check them in as is, when travelling from here (Malaysia) - also take a few in carryon. But if airlines like Qantas might be a bit anal about number of checkin pieces. You could try zip tying a couple together back to back. I’ve done this on a number of occasions and it saves the inconvenience of having to carry a otherwise useless bag around with you. I also like the idea of plastic wrapping two together at one of those machines they have in the terminal. My wife has done that before.
data.author: Graeme Maher

data.text: If You want to reduce nber of pieces, put them in a huge bag (eg Ortlieb Extremer drybag, chinese shopping bag). Simple. Forget zip ties.
data.author: Supp Suppinger

data.text: Then do what with this huge bag, genius? Lug it around the whole tour like some sort of arrestor parachute?
data.author: Graeme Maher

data.text: flame bait! Indeed, it serves well as a ground cover for tent or to sit on…
data.author: Sander Van Den Akker

data.text: there are multiple uses for this kind af durable, waterproof (depends) and lightweight fabric. Re-use. The weight isn´t an issue (at least not for me). Tent ground sheet, etc.
data.author: Supp Suppinger

data.text: At the risk of sounding fatuous - You could try carrying less stuff - I’ve just done 3 weeks bike cycling with two small panniers and realised I was carrying way too many clothes - ( I wasn’t camping) and normally when away for a few days just take one pannier -
data.author: Chris Steven Green

data.text: Box it all up and and put into oversize luggage just make sure you tape the box all the way round length and widths i used to do that with my carp fishing tackle i used to take down under..did lots of trips over a period of 10 years leaving what i took over in storage ready for my next trip
data.author: Raymond Stevens

data.text: We used a yachting bag which is a backpack style. Put one pannier inside with extras and checked it in. The other pannier and our helmets we carried on as hand luggage. When we rode we put the yachting bag sideways across the panniers strapped with okkie straps and packed it with lunch things, wind jacket, spare clothes which maybe needed during the day. This saves opening up the panniers at all during the day. Also if taking bikes on a train you can put your stuff in the backpack and put it on your back and manage the stairs whilst pushing your bike up. The backpack was also handy if you can staying at a B&B. Good luck.
data.author: Phillip Biencourt

data.text: We take each set of panniers and wrap them in kitchen plastic wrap. on the last couple of "wraps", stick a piece of paper in the next layer or two with my name and other information in case they get lost.
data.author: Chuck Atkinson

data.text: We use Lowland outdoor flightbags + tape. 4 Ortlieb bags fit perfectly.
data.author: Jovan Dierkx

data.text: I have a duffle bag that holds two rear panniers,helmet,shoes,handle bar bag and water bottles. I carryv2vrear panniers. My rack pack is 2nd bag
data.author: Dean Derek

data.text: Any kind of sturdy cover should do it. Just have in mind for the staff in charge of getting the stuff to the plane everything has to go really fast and there is a transport system in the airport which dislike any hooks or straps as this might cause the item to get stuck or clinge to other item's. So a sturdy backsized cover comes handy
data.author: Achim Marke

data.text: Fits all my panniers. When available I use the wrapping service on the airport for extra protection. Extra cost is 10-15 euro.
data.author: Oscar Mager

data.text: IKEA Frakta trolley bag.
data.author: Stipe Stajp Predanic

data.text: Some paniers i just put them in the bike box, the other two i just strap them together (one of them empty the other full) and take them as carry on
data.author: Tomas Aperlo

data.text: I've gotten one of those heavy duty but inexpensive plastic bags you find and discount shops - they are often plaid. A few panniers can fit into one, zip it up, tag it and check it in.
data.author: Elizabeth Cage

data.text: my choice too
data.author: Andrew Short

data.text: me too, so much easier and no hassles from airlines
data.author: Jude Willett

data.text: We've used these bags too. They are not that strong, but better if you wrap some strong tape around them. You can also sometimes find an old duffel bag at a thrift shop.
data.author: Margo Mactaggart

data.text: I love this! Thank you 🙏
data.author: Serendipitous Sojourn

data.text: There is travel chaos in Europe at present. Prepare for cancellations if you have to change planes or simply for lost/delayed panniers
data.author: Stefan Ilcus

data.text: A cardbord box. Available anywhere and can be thrown away at the airport when arriving.
data.author: Søren Rosenius Olsen

data.text: I used a nylon laundry bag. All 4 of my panniers fit in it. The laundry bags are pretty tough, but I doubled them up, just in case... they fold up very small. Package of two from Amazon. I tucked the drawstrings into the bag as I pulled it tight.
data.author: Tom Little

data.text: We used a big clear garbage bag and duct taped it. One airline allowed that but when we went on to the next airline they said no. We needed an actual bag.
data.author: Denise Sauer

data.text: I put them in chicken feed bags, coming back from Scotland,,.
data.author: Robert Clark

data.text: Huge duffle
data.author: Darin Dunn

data.text: I buy used luggage at a thrift store, then donate it when I get to my destination. My last trip I found a duffle bag with wheels.
data.author: Scott J. Mansfield

data.text: Vaude: Travel and Tarp
data.author: Frank Mac Oil

data.text: A cardboard box
data.author: Marco Peccatori

data.text: I put my empty panniers, helmet, shoes, waterbottles with the bike in bike box for flight; pannier contents in compression bags fit into a 40L REI light duffel bag I could wear as a backpack; this is also how I did two train movements, with weight on my back, empty panniers.
data.author: Kathy Swords

data.text: Airplane carrier bag 200 grs by Amazon
data.author: Helene Revillard

data.text: I live in NZ - hope you don’t mind me asking - how did you organise to get the bikes in Europe? Thanks.
data.author: Mathea Roorda

data.text: most airlines have a flat rate fee for bikes, $45 to $55 ish depending on the airline
data.author: Dom Fournier

data.text: lots of research and emails to shops etc. Started looking in London but ended up buying from bikeplanet in Haarlem Netherlands and adjusted our travel plans to suit. They have been holding bikes in stocks for us, great with communication etc.
data.author: Adrian Yurisich

data.text: Carried my two panniers on the plane as hand luggage when flying in Europe
data.author: Peter Graham

data.text: In with your bike and GOTO your local salves and buy a cheap suit case and put them in.
data.author: Pope Jp

data.text: Mera linda 🚴‍♀️🚴‍♀️🚴‍♀️﹪﹊〃
data.author: Elmer Detering

data.text: Beautiful beautiful 。 =?
data.author: Hubert Wilczewski

data.text: Cardboard box.....
data.author: Tim Hobin

data.text: I use a large cardboard box or two to put the items In as well as the panniers flat. Repack on arrival. Maybe use one as a carry on bag.
data.author: Phil Coran

data.text: Put them into a couple of sturdy duffel bags. Find them used at thrift stores then leave the duffels behind.
data.author: Robin Brodsky

data.text: Like this: Three in the bag, one as a carry on and my bike in its canvas bag shrink wrapped.
data.author: David Gibson

data.text: Hi, I usually buy a cheap $5- $10 suitcase from an op shop (Goodwill Store)..fill with my bike gear, and discard/give away on arrival.😎
data.author: Hamish Blanch

data.text: put them in a burlap sack and wrap with duct tape? I once got a kit bag from army surplus, it cost 5€. It is worth the spent, because the belts and buckles of panniers tend to snag on those conveyor belts. The most popular reason for luggage to get delayed. Garbage bags are not such a good odea, not solid enough.
data.author: Michaela Eff

data.text: I bought a small car and packed the panniers in the boot (trunk) of the car. Check-in went relatively smoothly.
data.author: Graeme Maher

data.text: Just a cardboard packing box from Uhaul, etc. We had 2. Put front and rear packed panniers inside. We we only charged for our 2nd check luggage from Delta, Seattle to Amsterdam.
data.author: Frosene Sacco

data.text: Ikea bag for 2 big panniera was just fine..one i had like a hand luggage and 2 smaller fits in our backpack (because we also hike)..
data.author: Anchica Chobot

data.text: I buy a $35 duffel bag from Amazon, put my panniers in it and then throw it away when I land.
data.author: Scott Diamond

data.text: We usually packed them in a sturdy bag. You might need two.
data.author: GeniPeter Hart

data.text: Our two full sized touring bikes with S&S couplers plus gear. Each bag is less than 40 pounds and checked as luggage with no additional charge. Our panniers are our carryons.
data.author: Rod Wanker

data.text: My bike with the bike travel bags rolled up on the front rack.
data.author: Rod Wanker
